article.paragraph: Ahmed I(lang-otaاحمد اولtranslotaAḥmed-i evvel;lang-trI. Ahmed; April 18, 1590 November 22, 1617) was theSultan of the Ottoman Empirefrom 1603 until his death in 1617.
article.heading: Reign
article.paragraph: File:Blue Mosque.jpgthumb262pxTheSultan Ahmed Mosque.In the earlier part of his reign Ahmed I showed decision and vigor, which were belied by his subsequent conduct. The wars which attended his accession both inHungaryand inIranPersiaterminated unfavourably for the empire, and its prestige received its first check in theTreaty of SitvatorokTreaty of Zsitvatorok, signed in 1606, whereby the annual tribute paid byAustriawas abolished. Following the crushing defeat in theOttomanSafavid War (160318)against the neighbouring rivallingSafavid Empireled by ShahAbbas the Great,Georgia (country)Georgia,Azerbaijanand other vast territories in the Caucasus were ceded back to Persia per theTreaty of Nasuh Pashain 1612, territories which had earlier been temporarily conquered per the outcoming result of theOttomanSafavid War (157890). The new borders were drawn per the exact same line as confirmed in thePeace of Amasyaof 1555.Ga bor A goston,Bruce Alan Masters''Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire''pp 23 Infobase Publishing, 1 jan. 2009 ISBN 1438110251
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: Ahmed I's mother wasValide SultanValideHandan Sultan, an ethnicGreeksGreekwho was originally named Helena. He was born atManisaPalace. He succeeded his fatherMehmed III(r. 1595–1603) in 1603 at age 13. He broke with the traditional fratricide and sent his brother Mustafa to live at the old palace at Bayezit along with their grandmother Safiye Sultan. He was known for his skills in fencing, poetry, horseback riding, and fluency in numerous languages. A half-brother of Ahmed,Sultan YahyaYahya, resented his accession to the Ottoman throne in 1603, and spent his life scheming to become Sultan.

Ahmed was a poet who wrote a number of political and lyrical works under the name Bahti. But while supportive of poetry, he displayed an aversion to artistry and continued his father's neglect ofOttoman miniatureminiature painting.Citation needed"Works of fiction are not reliable sources, no matter how excellent"December 2013This was connected to a devout religiosity that declared depiction of living things in art an immoral rivalry toAllah's creation.cite webhttp://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/figs/hd_figs.htmFigural Representation in Islamic Art | Thematic Essay | Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History | The Metropolitan Museum of ArtMetmuseum.org2012-01-26Accordingly, Ahmed patronized scholars, calligraphers, and pious men. Hence he commissioned a book entitledThe Quintessence of Historiesto be worked upon by calligraphers. He also attempted to enforce conformance to Islamic laws and traditions, restoring the old regulations that prohibited alcohol and he attempted to enforce attendance atJumu'ahFriday prayersand paying alms to the poor in the proper way.

He was responsible for the destruction of the musical clock organ thatElizabeth I of Englandsent to the court during the reign of his father.cite webJardineLisahttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7155903.stmUK | Magazine | An eye for detailBBC News2007-12-212012-01-26The reason for this may have been Ahmed's religious objection to figurative art or the fact that the complex organ served as a daily reminder of the waxing influence and power of the West.
Ahmed I died oftyphusin 1617.File:Istanbul - Tomba Ahmet I.JPGthumb262pxHistrbe.

article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: File:Savary Franco Ottoman Capitulations 1615.jpgthumbBilingual Franco-Turkish translation of the 1604Franco-Ottoman allianceFranco-Ottoman Capitulationsbetween Ahmed I andHenry IV of France, published byFranois Savary de Brvesin 1615.cite bookhttp://books.google.com/books?id''The Encyclopaedia of Islam: Fascicules 111-112 : Masrah Mawlid'' by Clifford Edmund Bosworth p.799Books.google.com2012-01-26Today, Ahmed I is remembered mainly for the construction of theSultan Ahmed Mosque(also known as theSultan Ahmed MosqueBlue Mosque), one of the masterpieces ofIslamic architecture. The area inFatiharound the Mosque is today called Sultanahmet. He died atTopkap PalaceinIstanbuland is buried in a mausoleum right outside the walls of the famous mosque.
